projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

2012-10 John PasText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: A DIALOGUE Between the Confederate Princes Concerning the Preſent AFFAIRS of EUROPE.

sp.speaker: The French King to the Jeſuits.
sp.p: FOR I ſpeak, and 'tis done— my Counſel ſhall ſtand, and I will do all my Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: The Jeſuits to King James.
sp.p: The Proteſtants truſted on the Lord that he would deliver them, Let him deliver them ſeeing he delighted in them.

sp.speaker: The Vaudois and the French Proteſtants.
sp.p: Our Perſecutors are ſwifter than the Eagles of the Heaven, the perſu'd Us upon the Mountains, they laid wait for Us in the Wilderneſs.
How long, O Lord, Holy and True doſt thou not Judge and Avenge our Blood on them that dwell on the Earth.

sp.speaker: The Church of England ſpeaking by the Mouth of the Biſhop of Bath and Wells.
sp.p: Rejoyce not againſt Me, O mine Enemy: If I am fallen, I will ariſe; if I have ſat in Darkneſs, the Lord will enlighten Me.

sp.speaker: The Lords and Nobility of England.
sp.p: The Jeſuits and the Monks part our Garments among them, and caſt Lots upon our Veſtures.

sp.speaker: Geneva and the Suiſſe Proteſtants.
sp.p: Therefore the Prudent ſhall keep ſilence,— for 'tis an Evil time.

sp.speaker: The Biſhop of St. Aſaph.
sp.p: Why are You fearful, O, Yea of little Faith? — For yet a little while, and he that ſhall come will come, and will not tarry.

sp.speaker: An Angel to the Prince of Orange.
sp.p: And another Angel came out of the Temple, crying with a Loud Voice, to the Prince of Orange, Thruſt in thy Sickle in England and Reap; for the time is come for thee to Reap; for the Harveſt of the Earth is Rine: Then he thruſt in his Sickle on the Earth, and the Earth was Reaped.

sp.speaker: All thoſe Princes and People that France Tyranizeth over.
sp.p: Now is come Salvation and Strength, and the Kingdom of our God, and the Power of his Chriſt; for James the Friend and Slave of Louis the Fourteenth is caſt down.

sp.speaker: The Duke of Savoy.
sp.p: For I am in a ſtrait betwixt Two (that is to ſay, Cazal and Pignerol) having a deſire to depart and to be with the Emperour, or with the Spaniard, which is far better.

sp.speaker: The Preachers of Paſſive Obedience to King James.
sp.p: Then ſaid all the Trees unto the Bromble, Come thou and Reign over Us.

sp.speaker: All True Engliſhment.
sp.p: But now ſo 'tis, that we have another King over Us, to Judge Us, and go out before Us and Fight our Battels.

sp.speaker: The Biſhop of London to the Parliament.
sp.p: Now as to Thee, the Eyes of all Iſrael are upon Thee, that thou ſhould'ſt tell them who ſhall ſit upon the Throne.

sp.speaker: The Pope apprehending the Exploits of King William.
sp.p: Ah! the Evils and great Calamities of the Holy See come always from the North.

sp.speaker: King James ſpeaking to the Jeſuits in the Colledge of Clermont.
sp.p: Vanity of Vanities all is Vanity.
For a day in thy Courts is better than a Thouſand elſewhere, and I had rather be a Door keeper to the Jeſuits, than to wear a Crown amongſt the Tents of the Wicked Hereticks.

sp.speaker: Hamborough.
sp.p: Mine Adverſary the Devil walketh about mee, as a Roaring Lyon ſeeking to Devour mee.

sp.speaker: Brandebourg and Lunebourg to Hambourg.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt tread upon the Lyon and Adder — We will make perfect our ſtrength in thy Weekneſs.

sp.speaker: The King of Denmark, of the Duke of Holſtein.
sp.p: Ah! ah! Our Soul, We have ſwallowed him up.

sp.speaker: The Duke of Holſtein.
sp.p: I will bring forth out of thy Mouth, that which thou haſt ſwallowed up.
He ſhall reſtore what he hath taken away by Force, and what he ſhall take by force, or what he hath taken by Circumvention.

sp.speaker: Monſieur Mazius an old Preacher of the King of Denmark.
sp.p: Maſter, We have Toyled all the Night and have taken Nothing.

sp.speaker: The good Cannons of Cologne.
sp.p:
We have choſen Clement of Bavaria, that
He may take part of this Miniſtry and Apoſtleſhip, from which Judas, the Cardinal of Furſtemberg by tranſgreſſion fell, that he might go to his own Place; for he having purchaſed Voices with the Reward of Iniquity, His Biſhoprick let another take.

sp.speaker: Cardinal Fuſtemberg.
sp.p: I have Conceived, I have been in Pain, and I have brought forth nothing but Wind.—

sp.speaker: The Parliament of England to King James upon his Abdication.
sp.p: So ſhall it befal all thoſe that forget God; and the deſignes of all Perfidious & Perjur'd perſons ſhall periſh, their hopes ſhall be Cut off, and their Truſt ſhall be a Spiders Web.

sp.speaker: The Parliament to the Prince of Orange.
sp.p: And all the People ſaid God ſave King William. And all the People came up after him, and play'd upon Flutes, and rejoyced with great Joy, to take the Oath of Allegiance to him.

sp.speaker: To the Arch Biſhop of Canterbury,
sp.p: And the Lord ſaid unto Samuel, how long wilt thou mourn for Saul, ſeeing I have rejected him from Reigning over Iſrael.

speaker.hi: All People concerned 〈◊〉 Liberty of Europe and for the True Religion.

sp.p: See you him whom the Lord hath Choſen, for their is none like him among all the People.

sp.speaker: God touching King William.
sp.p: But know that the Lord hath Choſen his well-beloved, And the Lord ſaid unto Samuel, Ariſe, Anoint him; for this is He.

And thou, Son of Man, be not afraid of them, neither be afraid of their words, tho Bryers and Thorns be with thee, and thou doſt dwell among Jacobites, Preachers of Paſſive Obedience: Inventors of the diſtinction between a King de Jure and de Facto; be not afraid of their words; for behold, I have made thy Face ſtrong againſt their Faces, and thy Forehead ſtrong againſt their Forheads.

sp.speaker: England with Roſes in her hands.
sp.p: The Flowers appear on the Earth, the time of the ſinging of Birds is come.
Under William have been laid the Foundations, which defend the Temple of the Lord, He is as the Flowers of Roſes in the ſpring time.

sp.speaker: Ireland holding her Harpe.
sp.p: We wept when we remembred Sion, We hanged our Harpes upon the Willowes; but now my heat is fixed. Awake Pſalter and Harp; I my ſelf will awake early, I will praiſe thee O Lord among the People: and I will ſing Praiſes unto thee among the Nations.

sp.speaker: Sco • and with her Thiſtles.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt, like Gideon, tear the Fleſh of thine Enemies with Thornes and Thiſtles; but my Thiſtles ſhall bear Figgs to thee.

sp.speaker: King William to the Highlanders and Fanaticks in Scotland.
sp.p: That Earth which beareth Thornes and Thiſtles is rejected, and is nigh unto Curſing, whoſe End is to be burned. But beloved, we are perſwaded better things of You, and things that accompany Salvation.

sp.speaker: The Duke of Savoy.
sp.p: Let us now break the Bands of France aſunder, and caſt away his Cords from Us.

sp.speaker: The King of England to that Duke.
sp.p: Whither thou go'ſt I will go, and where thou lodgeſt I will lodge; thy People is my People, and thy God is my God; where thou dieſt, will I die, and there will I be buried, the Lord do ſo to me, and more alſo, if ought but Death part Thee and Me.

sp.speaker: The Emperour haſtning to Crown his ſon King of the Romans.
sp.p: And conſidering moreover, that all the Neighboring Potentates are at War round about me, wayring for an Opportunity, and expecting what may happen, I have declar'd my ſon, my Succeſſour.

sp.speaker: The houſe of Lavembourg.
sp.p: And the great houſes ſhall have an End, ſaith the Lord.

sp.speaker: The three branches of the Houſe of Brunſwick.
sp.p: A threefold Cord, is not quickly broken, and we will take care of Lyvembourg.

sp.speaker: The Electors of Mayence, Treves, and the Biſhop of Liege; to the Emperour.
sp.p: Thou haſt made Us a ſtrife unto our Neighbours, and our Enemy the King of France laugheth at Us.

sp.speaker: The Dake of Wirtemberg, the Marquis of Dourlack, the Biſhops of Worms and Spire.
sp.p: Holdeſt Thou thy Tongue O Lord, when the wicked French King devoureth the man that is more righteous than He; and haſt thou made men as the Fiſhes of the Sea, where the great Ones devour the

sp.speaker: All the Confederates to the Emperour.
sp.p: Let God be Judge between You and Us; for You have done Us great Injury in not having made a Peace with the Aſſyriens, (Turcks.)

sp.speaker: Lorrain upon the Death of her Prince.
sp.p: Oh my Father! my Father!

sp.speaker: The Germans, and Confederates upon the death of the ſame.
sp.p: O the Chariots of Iſrael, and its Horſemen.

sp.speaker: The Emperour to the King of Poland.
sp.p: Wilt thou go with me to Battel to Ramoth-Gilead? (the Port.)

sp.speaker: The Venetians to the King of Poland.
sp.p: No man having put his hand to the Plough, and looking back is fit for the Kingdom of Heaven.

sp.speaker: The Hollanders to the King of Danemark.
sp.p: I know thy Works, that thou art neither Cold nor Hot, for the League, ſo then, becauſe thou art luke warme, I will ſpue the out of my Mouth.

sp.speaker: The Confedarates to the King of Sweden.
sp.p: Demas hath forſaken Us, having loved this preſent World.

sp.speaker: The King of England to the Suiſſes.
sp.p: How long halt Ye between two Opinions? If the Lord be God follow him: But if Baal be God — then follow him.

sp.speaker: The Vaudois.
sp.p: The Lord of Hoſt is with Us, the God of Jacob is our Refuge.

sp.speaker: The French concerning the Vaudois.
sp.p: Let us flee before theſe People for the Lord Fighteth for them.

sp.speaker: Louis the XIV. to the Duke de Chaulnes.
sp.p: Go you and tell that Fox, Pope Ottoboni, that he ought to have reſpect for Me; for behold I caſt out Devils, driving out of my Countrey, Carteſians, Janſeniſts, and Huguenots.

sp.speaker: The Pope to Cardinal Fourbin.
sp.p: All theſe things will I grant to the King of France, if he will fall down and worſhip Me.

sp.speaker: The French King to Tourville.
sp.p: Let the City of London be accurſt, and all the things that are therein, onely Rahab the Harlot (the Dutcheſs of Mazarin) ſhall live, ſhe and all that are with her in the houſe, becauſe ſhe carefully hid the Spics that we ſent.

sp.speaker: The Hollanders to Torrington and the Red Squadron.
sp.p: The Children of Ephraim turn'd their backs in the day of Battel.

sp.speaker: The true Engliſh.
sp.p: O Lord! what ſhall We ſay when Iſrael turneth their backs before their Enemies! For the Canaanites, the French, the Jacobites, the Drs. of Paſſive obedience ſhall hear of it, and ſhall environ Us round, and Cut off our Name from the Earth!

sp.speaker: King William concerning my Lord Torrington.
sp.p: If for the time to come He will ſhew himſelf a Worthy Man, there ſhall not an hair of him fall to the Earth: But if Wickedneſs ſhall be found in him, He ſhall dye.

sp.speaker: The Duke of Saxony, to the Duke of Bavaria Tobit,
sp.p: Eat, drink and be joyful, and take thy Reſt. Eat, drink and be merry.

sp.speaker: Prince Lowis of Baden, concerning the Army on the Rhine.
sp.p: I ſaw the German Army ſcatter'd upon the Rhine, as Sheep having no Shepherd.

sp.speaker: The Duke of Bavaria.
sp.p: Who is ſufficient for theſe things! Who am I, that I ſhould go againſt the Pharaoh of France, and that I ſhould bring forth the Germans out of Egypt?

sp.speaker: The Count de Caſtanaga, concerning the Amy of 66000 Men encamped at Hall.
sp.p: And Brandenbourgh and Waldeck did Eat and Drink, they and the Men that were with them, and tarried there all night (in the Spaniſh Netherlands.)
And they went out into the Fields, and gathered their Vineyards, and trod the Grapes and made merry, and did Eat and drink and curſed Abimelec (the French King) and that was all that they did.

sp.speaker: The Landtgrave of Heſſe concerning the ſame Army.
sp.p: The Harveſt truely is plenteous, but the Labourers are few: Pray Ye therefore the Lord of the Harveſt, that He will ſend forth Labourers into his harveſt.

sp.speaker: The French King to the Proteſtans Cantons.
sp.p:
The King of France to the Nation of the Suiſſe ſendeth Greeting; Where as Ye have kept Covenant with Us, and continued in our Friendſhip, not joyning your
ſelves with our Enemies, We have heard hereof and are Glad.
Wherefore now continue ſtill to be faithful unto Us; and we will recompenſe You, for the things you do in our behalf.
I will beſtow Penſions upon You, and will abate the Price of Salt.

I will raiſe 30000 Men amongſt You, under good Pay, I will ſend them into the beſt Garriſons, and let them walk in their own wayes and be govern'd by their own Laws, and their Captains ſhall be choſen from amongſt themſelves. They ſhall likewiſe be furniſhed at the King's Expence for fortifying the Paſſage of Aouſt.

sp.speaker: The Cantons.
sp.p: When they had heard theſe words, they believed them not, and would not accept of them; becauſe they remember'd the great Evil that he had done among them, and that he had greatly oppreſſed them, in uſurpeing the Franche Comté; and in building Huningen. But with William the III. they were well pleaſed, becauſe he was the firſt that entreated of true Peace with them.

sp.speaker: The Engliſh to the Queen Dowager.
sp.p: Better is a Neighbour that is near, than a Brother a far off.

sp.speaker: The Princeſſe of Denmark, concerning Mary of Modena.
sp.p: Before ſhe travailed ſhe brought forth: before her paines came, She was delivered of a Man-child. Who hath heard ſuch a thing! Who hath ſeen ſuch things!

sp.speaker: Same Dutch-Merchants.
sp.p: Who being met together ſaid, Sirs, You know that our Wealth proceeds from Trade. Now You ſee and hear, that our Craft is in great danger to be ſet at nought, if we continue to War with France.

sp.speaker: Saint Didier.
sp.p: Agree quickly with thine Adverſary Louis the XIV.

sp.speaker: The Count a Avaux.
sp.p: Now therefore ſhake hands with the Hollanders, and make Peace with them, and with all their Nation.
1 Theſſal. 5. v. 3.
And when they ſhall ſay Peace, and Safety, then ſudden deſtruction cometh upon them, as travail upon a Woman with Child; and they ſhall not eſcape.

sp.speaker: Myn Heer van Cirters to the Hollanders.
sp.p: The King of France ſhall ſwear unto You, and will ſoon after break his Oath.

sp.speaker: Myn Heer Odyke.
sp.p: Have no Dealings with the Wicked, nor with the Workers of Iniquity who ſpeak Peace to their Neighbours, but miſchief is in their hearts.

sp.speaker: Monſieur Hope.
sp.p: There is no Peace, ſaith my God, to the Wicked.

sp.speaker: Monſieur Dickvelt.
sp.p: What Concord hath Chriſt with Belial?

sp.speaker: Monſieur Henſius.
sp.p: What Agreement can there be between the Wolfe and the Sheep, muchleſs between the wicked, and that him ſeareth God?

sp.speaker: The truſty Blancart to the French King.
sp.p:
O full of all Subtlety and all Miſchief,
thou Child of the Devil, thou Enemy of all Righteouſneſs, wilt thou not ceaſe to pervert the Right ways of the Lord?

sp.speaker: The Dutch to the Engliſh.
sp.p: Every Kingdom divided againſt it ſelf is brought to Deſolation; and every City or Houſe divided againſt it ſelf ſhall not ſtand.

sp.speaker: The Elector of Brandenbourg to the Parliament of England.
sp.p: Are You ſo fooliſh? haveing begun in the Spirit, are you now made perfect by the Fleſh?

sp.speaker: The Torys to the Whiggs.
sp.p: Brethren you have been called unto Liberty; but uſe not Liberty for a Cloak to Wickedneſs.

sp.speaker: The Whiggs to the Tories.
sp.p: Curſed be He that confirmeth not all the words of the Law, to do them.

sp.speaker: A Trimmer.
sp.p: Let there be no Strife between Us, I pray thee, for We are Brethren; but what will you give me, and I will deliver him unto you.

sp.speaker: A Wigg.
sp.p: But in the beginning it was not ſo. To the Law and to the Teſtimony.
For, enquire, I pray thee, of the former Age, and prepare thy ſelf to the ſearch of their Fathers.

sp.speaker: A Patron of the good Old-Cauſe.
sp.p: Cloth thee, Cloth thee, Cloth thee with force, to Arme of the Lord; awake thou as in antient days, as in Ages paſt.

sp.speaker: A Tory.
sp.p: Defile not your ſelves in the Steps of your Forefathers. The Law is a • ainiſtry of Death; for the Letter killeth, but the Spirit giveth Life. There where the Spirit is, there is Truth alſo, the Old things are paſſed away and all things are made New.

sp.speaker: A Trimming Clergy-Man.
sp.p: For if this Counſel, or this Work of William the III. be of Men, it will come to nought: but if it be of God, Ye cannot overthrow it.

sp.speaker: Dr. Tillotſon to the People.
sp.p: But if you bite and devour one another, take heed that ye be not conſumed one of another.

sp.speaker: The ſame to the King.
sp.p: Thou ſhall provide out of all the People, able Men, ſuch as fear God, Men of Truth hateing covetouſneſs; and place ſuch over them, and give ſuch Employments, ſo ſhall all the People go to their Place in peace.

sp.speaker: The Prayers of Europe againſt the French King.
sp.p: O God! who art my King of old, working Salvation in the midſt of the Earth, deſtroy thou this Behemoth, and break the Head of this Leviathan.

sp.speaker: The Janſeniſts, the Proteſtants & the Carteſians, concerning the Fall of Behemoth.
sp.p: Thou haſt ſaid in thine heart, I will aſcend into Heaven, I will exalt my Throne above the Starrs of God. I will be like the moſt High.
How art thou fallen from Heaven, ô Lucifer, Son of the morning? how art thou cut down to the Ground, which didſt weaken the Nations.
They that ſee thee, they ſhall narrowly look upon thee, and conſider thee, ſaying, is not this Louis the Great that made the Earth to tremble, that did ſhake Kingdoms?

sp.speaker: The Venetians, and the Duke of Tuſcany, whiſpering him in the Ear.
sp.p: There is no healing of thy Bruiſe: thy wound is grievous: all that hear the bruit of thee ſhall clap the hands over thee: for upon whom hath not thy Wickedneſs paſſed continually?

sp.speaker: The Jacobites, the Preachers of Paſſive Obedience, the Inventors of the Diſtinction of a King de Jure & de Facto, the Murmurers, the French Penſioners.
sp.p: They ſhall weep and wayle and put on Mourning for the fall of Behemot, beating their Breaſts and ſaying; alas! how in one inſtant ſo great Richeſs are come to Nought!

sp.speaker: The Emporour touching Belgrade.
sp.p: Mine yeſterday, the Turks to day.

sp.speaker: The Duke of Lorrains Ghoſt to the Emperour.
sp.p: Yet now be ſtrong, ſaith the Lord, and leave off Muſick in the time of Mourning.

sp.speaker: Prince Louis of Baden to his Imperial Majeſty.
sp.p: The Jeſuits are Deceitful Workers; They allways cauſe vexation, & trouble to Princes; and by reaſon of thoſe that are in great Place and credit they continue dayly in their Power, encreaſing in malice, and being great Traytors to your Majeſty.
Murders, Strifes, Battels, Aſſaults, Famine, Deſtruction, Puniſhments, all theſe things are ordained for the Unjuſt, and by their Fault is the Deluge come, which hath overflowed Hungary.

sp.speaker: Monſieur Hofman, the Emperours Secretary, concerning the Engliſh Court.
sp.p: What I have heard is true, and as true as God liveth.

div.p: LONDON. Printed for H. Hills, in Black-Fryers, and T. Jones, without Temple-Bar. 1691.
